linkTarget.anchoringText: The Yuri Korchagin field is located in shallow waters, within the Russian border of the North Caspian sea, which is illustrated geographically in Figure 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Yuri Korchagin field location/ Russian part of North Caspian

formatted-caption.caption-text: Yuri Korchagin field location/ Russian part of North Caspian

linkTarget.anchoringText: The field was discovered in 2000, where the first exploration well discovered a massive stratigraphic feature: from the Middle Jurassic up to Paleoigene deposits. It is an oil-gas-condensate, thin oil rim clastic reservoir with an average thickness of 20 metres, bounded by a massive gas cap approximately 100 metres in height and an underlying active aquifer shown in Figure 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Neocom geological cross section

formatted-caption.caption-text: Neocom geological cross section

linkTarget.anchoringText: The current oil rim development strategy is to continue to drill 5000 metre horizontal section of producing wells, radially out from the platform close to the WOC in order to minimise early gas coning and breakthrough as illustrated in Figure 3 and Figure 4. In addition, any produced gas is re-injected into the gas cap and produced water is re-injected into the water bearing zone.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Neocom Drilling scheme

formatted-caption.caption-text: Neocom Drilling scheme

linkTarget.anchoringText: The current oil rim development strategy is to continue to drill 5000 metre horizontal section of producing wells, radially out from the platform close to the WOC in order to minimise early gas coning and breakthrough as illustrated in Figure 3 and Figure 4. In addition, any produced gas is re-injected into the gas cap and produced water is re-injected into the water bearing zone.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Well placement trajectory

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well placement trajectory

linkTarget.anchoringText: There are currently 16 producing wells, with the majority of them producing above a design GOR of 104 m3/m3. The longest producing wells already exceed this value by twenty times or more as illustrated in Figure 5 as GOR bubble maps.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: GOR bubble map

formatted-caption.caption-text: GOR bubble map

linkTarget.anchoringText: To mitigate gas coning, it was expected that PICD could be used to balance inflow and choke gas upon breakthrough but did not sufficiently choke gas inflow. Even with a low drawdown (between 3 to 6 bars), the GOR steadily increases with no sign of abating as illustrated in Figure 6. Some PICD wells have a producing GOR of 2500 m3/m3, which is almost 25 times more than the design GOR.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Steady GOR increase in PICD wells

formatted-caption.caption-text: Steady GOR increase in PICD wells

linkTarget.anchoringText: With this constraint in mind, it is only possible by moving the drilling portal to the stern and freeing two rows of slots on the spider desk as shown in Figure 7 and setting up an upper roller for the lubricator requires the use of a deck crane. Therefore, this creates additional complications for scheduling loading operations between escort vessels and the platform. For these reasons, PLTs were ruled out as an unfeasible and complicated monitoring option.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Slots position on the platform

formatted-caption.caption-text: Slots position on the platform

linkTarget.anchoringText: The RCP based AICD was the chosen design by the Yuri Korchagin asset team to pilot because of the similar reservoir and fluid property characteristics and same primary challenge of controlling gas inflow from the gas cap like Troll. The actual valves deployed in the pilot well are shown from the selected vendor in Figure 8.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Photograph on the left shows a RCP AICD installed at the end of the screen joint with the housing removed. The two illustrations on the right show a cross section of the RCP AICD with the movable disc and arrows indicating the flow path around the device

formatted-caption.caption-text: Photograph on the left shows a RCP AICD installed at the end of the screen joint with the housing removed. The two illustrations on the right show a cross section of the RCP AICD with the movable disc and arrows indicating the flow path around the device

linkTarget.anchoringText: The inflow tracer systems are unique tracer molecules embedded in a polymer matrix material, in the shape of rods as shown in Figure 9. This combination is classified as a tracer system. Water tracer systems are designed to release tracer material to water and oil tracer systems are designed to release tracer material to oil. The tracer release rate is independent of fluid velocity passing the polymer matrix; release changes with the degree of target fluid contact called wetting. Both oil and water tracer systems are dormant when not in contact with their target phase. This also means if a gaseous phase is in contact with either oil or water tracer systems, no tracers will be released at all. The absence of tracer from a particular location can also indicate there is no flow, meaning no wetting from a target fluid.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Tracer systems are the rod shaped polymers. They are installed in wire wrap screen filters drainage layer housed by the rib wires, base pipe OD and ID of wire wrap

formatted-caption.caption-text: Tracer systems are the rod shaped polymers. They are installed in wire wrap screen filters drainage layer housed by the rib wires, base pipe OD and ID of wire wrap

linkTarget.anchoringText: The LWD log interpretation indicated the thickness of the Middle Neocom lessened eastwards and changed by ~5 metres in the drilling interval of 2020 –2110 metre and by ~1 metre between 5800 – 6120 metre interval. The reservoir is characterized by a high degree of heterogeneity and is complicated by lens-like inclusions of dense carbonized sandstone. Outside the dome of the reservoir, the reservoir properties reduce in quality, the oil saturated sandstone became increasingly interbedded by carbonized rocks. The final well placement interpretation can be seen in Figure 10.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Final pilot well placement

formatted-caption.caption-text: Final pilot well placement

linkTarget.anchoringText: The pilot well was drilled and completed on the 15th of October, 2014, sixteen compartments were isolated with swell packers in the open hole annulus. It is important to note that the tracers are only indicative of flow between packers. After the LWD logs were interpreted, the asset team identified where to place the swell packers and the eight chemical sensors in the lower completion, meaning the other eight remaining zones are unmonitored or without sensors and therefore termed as “blind zones”. The chemical sensor placement strategy was to position each sensor in separate completion compartments which had good quality sands and stay approximately 5 metres above the OWC. In addition, the blind zones adjacent to the monitored zones were also placed near sands of similar sand quality. The final placement of the eight chemical sensors along the horizontal producing interval is illustrated in Figure 11 and Figure 12.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Tracer systems placement and “blind” zones in the pilot well. The illustrate undulating well trajectory with the highlighted circles indicates the highest elevated intervals of the well nearest to the GOC

formatted-caption.caption-text: Tracer systems placement and “blind” zones in the pilot well. The illustrate undulating well trajectory with the highlighted circles indicates the highest elevated intervals of the well nearest to the GOC

linkTarget.anchoringText: The pilot well was drilled and completed on the 15th of October, 2014, sixteen compartments were isolated with swell packers in the open hole annulus. It is important to note that the tracers are only indicative of flow between packers. After the LWD logs were interpreted, the asset team identified where to place the swell packers and the eight chemical sensors in the lower completion, meaning the other eight remaining zones are unmonitored or without sensors and therefore termed as “blind zones”. The chemical sensor placement strategy was to position each sensor in separate completion compartments which had good quality sands and stay approximately 5 metres above the OWC. In addition, the blind zones adjacent to the monitored zones were also placed near sands of similar sand quality. The final placement of the eight chemical sensors along the horizontal producing interval is illustrated in Figure 11 and Figure 12.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Lower completion configuration with geology log and tracer placement. (B – “blind” zones not monitored by tracers)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Lower completion configuration with geology log and tracer placement. (B – “blind” zones not monitored by tracers)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Prior to restarting the well, it was shut in for a 36 hour period. The well was started at a choke setting 16.67mm and 88 oil samples were collected during the restart. Based on the well production data in Figure 14 and well construction from downhole to sampling point, 42 samples were collected to be analysed for 8 oil tracers as shown in Figure 13. The measured normalised tracer concentrations in the oil samples are shown in Figure 15 and Figure 16.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Collected (black triangles) and analyzed (red triangles) samples for oil tracers, production rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Collected (black triangles) and analyzed (red triangles) samples for oil tracers, production rate

Based on the well production data in Figure 14 and well construction from downhole to sampling point, 42 samples were collected to be analysed for 8 oil tracers as shown in Figure 13. The measured normalised tracer concentrations in the oil samples are shown in Figure 15 and Figure 16.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Pilot well re-start production data

Based on the well production data in Figure 14 and well construction from downhole to sampling point, 42 samples were collected to be analysed for 8 oil tracers as shown in Figure 13. linkTarget.anchoringText: Prior to restarting the well, it was shut in for a 36 hour period. The well was started at a choke setting 16.67mm and 88 oil samples were collected during the restart. Based on the well production data in Figure 14 and well construction from downhole to sampling point, 42 samples were collected to be analysed for 8 oil tracers as shown in Figure 13. The measured normalised tracer concentrations in the oil samples are shown in Figure 15 and Figure 16.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Tracer signals during steady-state production

linkTarget.anchoringText: The basis for this model relies on the rate of change of the back produced released tracer molecules, which is dependent on the flow rate past the respective chemical sensor. For instance, in a high permeability production interval, a high tracer concentration response will be observed to rapidly decline towards steady-state or a near constant level. From a section with comparably lower permeability, a slower rate of decline is observed. This principle is illustrated in Figure 17.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Theoretical response dependency on section flow rate. A higher flow rate (2Q) gives an initially higher and more rapidly declining tracer response than a section with lower production rate (Q) assuming all other parameters kept constant

formatted-caption.caption-text: Theoretical response dependency on section flow rate. A higher flow rate (2Q) gives an initially higher and more rapidly declining tracer response than a section with lower production rate (Q) assuming all other parameters kept constant

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Flush-out model forms the basis for history matching and the estimation of zonal contribution and the details of the model can be found in (Montes et al., 2013). It was utilised to estimate zonal contribution in a nozzle based PICD lower completion compartmentalized with swell packers. The model described was applied to the family of tracer responses from the zones with chemical sensors installed as shown in Figure 18.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Tracer transients used for quantification

formatted-caption.caption-text: Tracer transients used for quantification

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Flush-out model forms the basis for history matching and the estimation of zonal contribution and the details of the model can be found in (Montes et al., 2013). It was utilised to estimate zonal contribution in a nozzle based PICD lower completion compartmentalized with swell packers. The model described was applied to the family of tracer responses from the zones with chemical sensors installed as shown in Figure 18. The modelled Flush-out functions were fitted to the measured tracer responses in Figure 19.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Fitting of the “Flushout” model tracer signal to measured signal (K – curvature of the modelled signal, normalized inflow at tracer location in percents)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Fitting of the “Flushout” model tracer signal to measured signal (K – curvature of the modelled signal, normalized inflow at tracer location in percents)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Using model fitted results and considering the relative compartment lengths and the permeability adjacent to the monitored and blind zones, the approximation of the relative inflow in the blind zones were determined. Inflow from every zone is normalized and expressed in percentage terms of the total well production rate taken as 100%. The results of the quantitative estimation of the zonal inflow distribution including contribution from the blind zones are summarised in Table 2 and presented graphically in Figure 20.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Quantitative inflow distribution estimation summary

formatted-caption.caption-text: Quantitative inflow distribution estimation summary
